												After 14 minutes of trying to make an account and get Uplay to work, it's locked me out of my account due to too many log in attempts.HOW!? The account didn't even exist before now!The support section gave me a phone number to call which told me to hang up and use their 24/7 online chat which is down.Somehow Uplay is worse then GFWL.Fustrations with Uplay aside this is a mostly solid action game.The space bar is really contextual and has occasionally sent Sam out the window next to the laptop I wanted to hack. Gun play is solid. Most upgrades, such as gloves and goggles, are linear and missed a good chance for real customization. The game has the Ratchet and Clank problem where everything is expensive, but your showered in funds anyways.The biggest adjustment in the game is getting use to contextually wall climbing. It's funny how this is the company that popularized open world traversal.The first few levels are a pain, but after that open up to allow for creativity. There are side missions for stealth, kill everyone, and wave biased survival that can all be played co-op. There are even co-op only routes and missions, which I can see bugging anyone who didn't get this game with a friend.The biggest complaint I have (beyond Uplay) is the dirty lens effect. There is some kind of filter over the game that adds oil and dirt marks to the screen whenever a light is vaguely facing you. It's distracting and doesn't add anything to the game or atmosphere.Over all solid military stealth shooter. Not as bogged down as MGS.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Let's see ... 18hrs, and most of them are CO-OP missions, and played only 1 story mission. (for archievement)I'm having a blast with it so far with my friend. I won't go into details, but more on the thought. Here's my opinion;::: Game-Related :::The game itself is great, one of the best stealth action I played so far. It is a little more fast-paced compared to older games in the same series. Gameplay is fast, well, if you are going for Perfectionist. (the hardest difficulty)The game brings back execute system (with some improvement), where you tag enemies, and down all of the tagged within your reach using one button. It can be a very deadly aresenal together with the Sonar Vision (x-ray). It is a bit overpowered, but still, it is nice addition to have. However, playing on Perfectionist disabled both Tagged-Execution, and Sonar. This is where the fun is!You have several equipments your disposal, which affect your playstyle. How you play, is up to you, but in the end, it will put you into 3 groups, Ghost (non-lethal, stealth), Panther (lethal, stealth), and Assault (go all loud). I found that each style balanced quite well, so it depends on your preference.AI is nice, although it not that smart, but it is challenging enough to keep the game in its pace. You cannot sit in the shadow, looking into enemy's eye at almost arm-length. You can be spot if you cross its LOS.I haven't go deep into story (at all), but it seems okay, simple plot, but interesting. I am into CO-OP more, which is very good actually. The CO-OP content may seems small, but there is more than it seems, I am still playing it after 18hrs :DSpies Vs Mercs multiplayer looks interesting too, however, there is no anti-hack, and you will find hackers in public match, a lot. I tried it for likes 3-4 different matches. All of them have at least 1 obvious hacker, well, you know, speed hack, and wall-clipping hack, which is quite nasty. There are several other hacks available too (from what I found when reading around forums), likes wallhack, god mode, and etc.Apart from the (great) game itself, there is a critical flaw, Uplay.::: Uplay :::I have to say that Uplay has improved a lot compared to the time of its introduction. It looks really nice, comparing Uplay to Steam. However, Steam is more stable imo. Uplay has improved, and became more stable to let you enjoy your game, still, it acts weird on me several times, likes cannot login, cannot find server, logged in, but appeared offline in-game and etc. It is not really bad, but it is more of the annoyance in its current stage.Though, I can say that it is good when it is working. I like its UI more than Steam's :D::: Overall :::Very good game, grab a friend, get deluxe editions (for completed DLC package). Although, you will need some motivation to fiddle with Uplay along the way. I recommended this game for co-op experience! It is worth my purchase.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Renowned stealth spy Sam Fisher is back with a different voice. Gone is the brusque voice played by actor Michael Ironside, in is Eric Johnson. Sam’s voice is still credible and is now smoother than it used to be, but not as great as in previous Splinter Cell iterations.As Sam Fisher, you still work for the 4th Echelon, but this time you receive missions from a plane based in Greenland called The Paladin. The Paladin is the command center where you meet up with Anna Grimsdottir and the plot plays much like a political thriller. The story focuses on a group of terrorists trying to kill a series of targets in the United States. There’s quite a bit of tension in the plot and some of it is between Sam and his colleagues. Charlie Cole is an expert hacker who can annoy other employees in The Paladin. The story isn’t so much about Sam, but it is more about information warfare. In this game information is power.The screens in the command center are all digital; there are campaign missions as well as side missions. There are several new gadgets in this game that are very interesting and very useful for both the campaign and side missions. You get to choose your gadgets on The Paladin before you embark on any campaign or side mission. The availability of the gadgets gives you a chance to experiment with them against the various hostiles you will encounter in various countries of the world. One of the most interesting gadgets is the Tri-Rotor, a drone that you can use to scope out a building you are trying to infiltrate. The drone can give you a fairly good idea where the hostiles are located so that you can stealthily get inside a building without being spotted.Old Splinter Cell gameplay mechanics have returned such as the cover system. You can take cover behind a wall, barricade, or box. You can knock out hostiles by sneaking up behind them like in previous iterations of the Splinter Cell franchise. A new mechanic that is introduced to this game called mark and execute. It is an ability to mark nearby hostiles, then automatically killing them with headshots in slow motion at the press of a button. It feels like an action hero move.The missions take place in a variety of countries such as Iran, Paraguay, Mexico, United Kingdom, Guantanamo Bay, and Philadelphia, USA. The best mission designs consist of ventilation shafts, rooftops, and cubicles of offices. The A.I. of the guards is for the most part very realistic and increase suspense as they get closer to your hiding location. They will react realistically when they see an unconscious or dead colleague. Seeing an unconscious or dead colleague forces them to change their patrol patterns. A guard also will wonder why a door is now open when it was previously closed. If Sam is spotted by a hostile(s) a shadow is left in the last location where he was spotted.The side missions are fun, although they turn into trial and error missions. There are no save points, so you will have to go through the mission from start to finish without making critical mistakes. These missions are assigned by Sam’s colleagues such as Grimsdottir, Cole, or Briggs. They can be played in single player or co-op. The side missions are structured so that you would need a co-op player alongside you in order to climb high walls or fences. Many of these missions require stealth, so being spotted means the end of a mission. Side missions may require you to hack into phones, computers, and other devices so that the 4th Echelon can secretly acquire intel from the terrorists. There is enough drama and suspense to justify playing side missions.Splinter Cell: Blacklist is a gripping thriller of a game that reminds of a political movie thriller centered on spying. The campaign missions are suspenseful and the side missions add replayability to the game if you can get by the frustrations of trial and error. I would recommend this game to anyone who is interested in spying, stealth, and drama.

												Let's see ... 18hrs, and most of them are CO-OP missions, and played only 1 story mission. (for archievement)I'm having a blast with it so far with my friend. I won't go into details, but more on the thought. Here's my opinion;::: Game-Related :::The game itself is great, one of the best stealth action I played so far. It is a little more fast-paced compared to older games in the same series. Gameplay is fast, well, if you are going for Perfectionist. (the hardest difficulty)The game brings back execute system (with some improvement), where you tag enemies, and down all of the tagged within your reach using one button. It can be a very deadly aresenal together with the Sonar Vision (x-ray). It is a bit overpowered, but still, it is nice addition to have. However, playing on Perfectionist disabled both Tagged-Execution, and Sonar. This is where the fun is!You have several equipments your disposal, which affect your playstyle. How you play, is up to you, but in the end, it will put you into 3 groups, Ghost (non-lethal, stealth), Panther (lethal, stealth), and Assault (go all loud). I found that each style balanced quite well, so it depends on your preference.AI is nice, although it not that smart, but it is challenging enough to keep the game in its pace. You cannot sit in the shadow, looking into enemy's eye at almost arm-length. You can be spot if you cross its LOS.I haven't go deep into story (at all), but it seems okay, simple plot, but interesting. I am into CO-OP more, which is very good actually. The CO-OP content may seems small, but there is more than it seems, I am still playing it after 18hrs :DSpies Vs Mercs multiplayer looks interesting too, however, there is no anti-hack, and you will find hackers in public match, a lot. I tried it for likes 3-4 different matches. All of them have at least 1 obvious hacker, well, you know, speed hack, and wall-clipping hack, which is quite nasty. There are several other hacks available too (from what I found when reading around forums), likes wallhack, god mode, and etc.Apart from the (great) game itself, there is a critical flaw, Uplay.::: Uplay :::I have to say that Uplay has improved a lot compared to the time of its introduction. It looks really nice, comparing Uplay to Steam. However, Steam is more stable imo. Uplay has improved, and became more stable to let you enjoy your game, still, it acts weird on me several times, likes cannot login, cannot find server, logged in, but appeared offline in-game and etc. It is not really bad, but it is more of the annoyance in its current stage.Though, I can say that it is good when it is working. I like its UI more than Steam's :D::: Overall :::Very good game, grab a friend, get deluxe editions (for completed DLC package). Although, you will need some motivation to fiddle with Uplay along the way. I recommended this game for co-op experience! It is worth my purchase.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												Well, this is my Commentary on the whole product. The whole product is more, then just the gameplay, but i will start with the gameplay. I have to say, that the gameplay is really good. Everyone, who did no-kills runs in the previous games, can do so in this one. You can do open, deadly runs; silent, deadly runs and no-kill, silent runs. The game acknowledges this three style and i find the game to be a bit easier on no-kill, silent runs. If you like Splinter Cell, than this is a good game to play, whoever there is one big problem:30min crashes.Every 30min the game crashes for no reason. It is a popular problem and i tried many of the popular solitions, but they did not work. So you have only 30min until the game crashes. This is a bit forgiving in campaign missions, because you have a lot of checkpoints, but it makes the extra mission increadible frustrating or impossible. Theses mission do not have permant checkpoints. If the game crashes the whole progress is lost and the multiplayer becomes inaccessible, if you ever get a connection to Ubisoft servers. The game came out in august 2013 and this bug is not yet fixed and there is no garanteed way to know if you will be affected. This is unexcusable.My second problem comes with "Shadownet" or Ubisofts fancy way to make a central server unavoidable. Do you remember, how you could or could not connect to specific games-server back then? If you could not connect to a specific server, you choose another server and the problem was gone. You can't do this with Shadownet. If you can't connect to Shadownet, you can't play the multiplayer, because dedicated servers are the devil.It is easy to understand, that i can not recommend a game, where the multiplayer does not work as good as from games from over 10 years ago (settlers 2, diablo 2, counterstrik 1.6) and you have a high chance to be plagued by a crash bug.Do not buy this game at anything more than ~5-6€ and it is best, if you got this 5-6€ for free. Play Dota2, CSGO, etc and get drops in form of items or cards. Sell this drops and buy SplinterCell with the drop money. This is probably the best way to enjoy this game.This is sad, because the gameplay is good, but i can not support ♥♥♥♥♥♥, lazy and idle developers and publishers with a general recommendation.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Renowned stealth spy Sam Fisher is back with a different voice. Gone is the brusque voice played by actor Michael Ironside, in is Eric Johnson. Sam’s voice is still credible and is now smoother than it used to be, but not as great as in previous Splinter Cell iterations.As Sam Fisher, you still work for the 4th Echelon, but this time you receive missions from a plane based in Greenland called The Paladin. The Paladin is the command center where you meet up with Anna Grimsdottir and the plot plays much like a political thriller. The story focuses on a group of terrorists trying to kill a series of targets in the United States. There’s quite a bit of tension in the plot and some of it is between Sam and his colleagues. Charlie Cole is an expert hacker who can annoy other employees in The Paladin. The story isn’t so much about Sam, but it is more about information warfare. In this game information is power.The screens in the command center are all digital; there are campaign missions as well as side missions. There are several new gadgets in this game that are very interesting and very useful for both the campaign and side missions. You get to choose your gadgets on The Paladin before you embark on any campaign or side mission. The availability of the gadgets gives you a chance to experiment with them against the various hostiles you will encounter in various countries of the world. One of the most interesting gadgets is the Tri-Rotor, a drone that you can use to scope out a building you are trying to infiltrate. The drone can give you a fairly good idea where the hostiles are located so that you can stealthily get inside a building without being spotted.Old Splinter Cell gameplay mechanics have returned such as the cover system. You can take cover behind a wall, barricade, or box. You can knock out hostiles by sneaking up behind them like in previous iterations of the Splinter Cell franchise. A new mechanic that is introduced to this game called mark and execute. It is an ability to mark nearby hostiles, then automatically killing them with headshots in slow motion at the press of a button. It feels like an action hero move.The missions take place in a variety of countries such as Iran, Paraguay, Mexico, United Kingdom, Guantanamo Bay, and Philadelphia, USA. The best mission designs consist of ventilation shafts, rooftops, and cubicles of offices. The A.I. of the guards is for the most part very realistic and increase suspense as they get closer to your hiding location. They will react realistically when they see an unconscious or dead colleague. Seeing an unconscious or dead colleague forces them to change their patrol patterns. A guard also will wonder why a door is now open when it was previously closed. If Sam is spotted by a hostile(s) a shadow is left in the last location where he was spotted.The side missions are fun, although they turn into trial and error missions. There are no save points, so you will have to go through the mission from start to finish without making critical mistakes. These missions are assigned by Sam’s colleagues such as Grimsdottir, Cole, or Briggs. They can be played in single player or co-op. The side missions are structured so that you would need a co-op player alongside you in order to climb high walls or fences. Many of these missions require stealth, so being spotted means the end of a mission. Side missions may require you to hack into phones, computers, and other devices so that the 4th Echelon can secretly acquire intel from the terrorists. There is enough drama and suspense to justify playing side missions.Splinter Cell: Blacklist is a gripping thriller of a game that reminds of a political movie thriller centered on spying. The campaign missions are suspenseful and the side missions add replayability to the game if you can get by the frustrations of trial and error. I would recommend this game to anyone who is interested in spying, stealth, and drama.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												To start off let me say this......This...is a DAMN good game. Now let me elaborate on that statement. Splinter Cell: Blacklist has taken Splinter Cell back to much needed stealth, back to its roots you could say. However, even by doing this they make it a new, refreshing feel to it, not just some reskin of Chaos Theory. With the games new 3 way level design 1.(kill all, be loud) 2.(Kill all, remain silent) and 3.(knock out, remain silent) 3 being my personal favorite. With this new system each and every level has so many different and unique design and ways of turning out, which makes for amazing adventure. This game is good, but it has its flaws here and there. A few things in this game don`t really add up when you start to think of them. One thing is that going by the games official wiki and information found in the previous games, "Sam Fisher was born on 17th April, 1957" and assuming that Blacklist takes place in 2013-2014 Sam would be around 56 years old. Now don`t get me wrong, grandpas can kick♥♥♥♥♥ just look at Metal Gear, but thats a story for another day. The reason I brought this up is because in Blacklist Ubisoft replaced Sam Fisher`s actor from Michael Ironside who had played Sam in all previous games, to Eric Johnson, claiming it was for "peformance capture". Well Ironside`s Fisher sounded like a man who could be in his 50`s, Johnson`s Fisher on the other hand sounds like an angry 20 year old. Seeing how they used Johnson for Capture this Sam also looks much like Johnson himself. which looks like Sam might have looked like...in his 20 - 30`s. All of this is really just more of a personal complaint and this may not effect your gameplay experiance at all however. Since I am talking about negatives I must say how certain weapons/tools can be almost overpowering at times, for example you can come across a crossbow which if aimed correctly can fire to the near end of a map and on hit the arrow releases a sleeping gas which can take out almost any guard in range of it, one time when I alerted them the guards crowded up in a big bunch, there were at least 5 - 7 of them and ONE shot with a gas arrow and they are ALL down. This as well is just a minor complaint on what I think is still a VERY good game and if on sale you should buy for sure!8.5/10 ign

Nothing new there, Metal Gear has always been known for the story, Splinter Cell for the fluid gameplay.With this title I was afraid they would try to go down the Metal Gear route, putting in way too many cutscenes. The story is solid and has its own charm which is a welcome break from all the angsty emo storylines infecting gaming atm.SC:Blacklist still has that slick stealth gameplay. I still haven't played a game/Series that does it better. Going full stealth with Tri-Rotor (drone), Sleeping gas, Proximity mines, EMP grenades/Stun gun?Assault? A hybrid? Not only can you but the game provides a variety of weapons/gadgets to supplement your playstyle.There is also a Multiplayer available but haven't even touched that yet. Game has a solid 30+ hours of content just in  the Single Player campaign. A major hit for me and worth picking up if you love stealth games. A sale is just the icing on the cake in this case.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Something was changed in Splinter Cell: Blacklist, and what's left is a frustrating shade of what it once was. I'll get my first niggle out of the way first: no Quicksave function. Die, get detected, anything that compromises the mission and you're back to the beginning in most cases. I can't overstate the sheer frustration this causes for me. I like perfect, stealthy run throughs - I derive my enjoyment from seeing how a situation went wrong and going back to a 'just prior' save to try a different tactic. I don't want to be bumped right back to the beginning, to hear the same conversations, to trudge through the same hallways just to get to where I was. It's limiting and non-sensical to ditch a quicksave function in a stealth game. Next up, the controls. No longer can you control the speed at which Sam moves with the mousewheel. Keyboard controls (although admittedly they can be mapped), do not feel intuitive. Sam feels clunky, a little on rails. The contextual actions he performs are jarring, sometimes unwelcome; mean to open that door instead of head into cover? It's 50/50 what will happen. I wanted to leapfrog a railing by a door, and instead booted it open in front of a small army all curious as to who this suicidal maniac was. It feels clumsy, and in a Splinter Cell game clumsy is something that will deal break everything. So what about combat? Admittedly, I'm a stealth nut, I avoid it. But even I get bummed out when, after not being seen across the map in perfect shadow, the body I drag back to the same (seemingly hidden) location is located as if it had flashing neon lights on it. In fact, I *do* have flashing neon lights on me and I wasn't spotted in the same location....but the body was. It's that kind of lazy gameplay that kills this for me. I love Splinter Cell. Adore it even. But something has been removed here and what's left doesn't feel like a Splinter Cell game. It doesn't have the same polish, the same sleekness or the same atmosphere.....hell, it doesn't have the same soul. I can see what Ubisoft have tried to do, and for the life of me I can't work out why it hasn't worked, but it hasn't. I can't figure out how this game got good reviews from fans of the genre, so the possibility exists that this is just my problem and not the game. But somehow I trust my gut and this game simply has not gripped me yet. I hope it does.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Given what a letdown Double Agent and Conviction were, I wasn't expecting anything special when I played the game. Yet despite using the same game engine as Conviction, the series finally returns to its stealth roots and delivers an amazing stealth game on par with Chaos Theory.One of the game's main strengths is in its map design. Each map is its own small, self-contained open world environment filled with hidden passageways and alternate routes. These secret paths are so common that you'll go out of your way to find them, and it's really rewarding to find, for example, an intricate set of pipes and ledges you can climb to pass by 8+ guards unnoticed.The other main draw is the game's sheer level of customizability. Each mission rewards you with cash that can be used to upgrade your armor, weapons and gadgets. Unlike previous games, you can now carry up to 8 gadgets, including a user operated drone and an ultra powerful crossbow (stun gun variant) with 4 different firing modes. In fact, you're supplied with so many gadgets that you can't even go through all of them in a single mission (assuming one used per guard).In addition, each mission provides a ranking system for 3 different playstyles: Ghost, Panther and Assault. A Ghost style is classic stealth, Assault style means getting detected and duking it out in combat, and Panther is somewhere in between. This mechanic alone is great for replayability since you have a reason to beat any given mission at least 3 times, each time being such a vastly different experience it's almost like playing a new level. For instance, you can beat a level without so much as knocking out a single guard, then play that level again making liberal use of frag grenades, incendiary grenades, proximity mines and sniper rifle shots.Even the missions themselves have much needed variety compared to previous titles. While there is the standard fare campaign, there's also about an equal amount of Grim missions  where your objective is to either neutralize X hostiles, hack 3 terminals or even fight off waves of enemies, and the missions themselves vary in how well suited they are to a particular playstyle.Probably my biggest complaint is the storyline. Given you can beat missions in more or less any order you want, it has the effect of making the plot feel disjointed and confusing. Then there's just something about the dialogue and voice acting that comes across as silly, as if you're watching a Spy Kids movie with adults. It got to the point where I would actually skip cutscenes I hadn't seen before. If you play games for story, you should probably look elsewhere.My other minor complaint is the lack of online activity, but that's forgivable given the game is already 4 years old.

												Behind the new coat of paint and a new Sam Fisher, Blacklist represents a return to form for the series. It doesn’t revolutionize Splinter Cell, but it manages a sharp trifecta of achievements — it’s open to new players, accessible to players from the series' major departure installment and a welcome invitation back to series regulars who missed the stealth focus that peaked with Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory. Blacklist refines what came before and makes for a great new beginning for the series.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												For a precision stealth game to be good, it must be consistant.  Enemies must behave realistically, but predictably on repeat runthroughs.  A tactic that works once on a section of a level must be repeatable.  This is where Blacklist fell apart for me.  I'd have a great strategy for getting through a level, and I'd be figuring the last part of it out when all of a sudden the patrol routes for the first 3/4 of the level change, and my tactics for getting to that final part are ineffective.  This would be a great feature if you wanted to play "remixes" of the levels and be forced to try new approaches, but it quickly becomes frustrating when you're close to finishing a level only to have it change on your next attempt.Aside from that, the story seems generic and boring, the enemies are hypersensitive, and it's more tedious than exciting most of the time.  Wouldn't hurt to try it if you see it cheap, otherwise check out Mark of The Ninja or Dishonored for a rewarding stealth experience.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Rather than stripping out quality stealth content for the sake of including action sequences or big set pieces, this game simply puts the icing on top of the cake, as it should be. There is a lot of game to be had here. A satisfyingly lengthy campaign, a breadth of side missions that encourage different styles of play, and rather robust multiplayer options, both competitive in the form of the beloved Spies vs. Mercs and cooperative versions of every side mission. The campaign itself and the story it tells is something between a summer blockbuster and an engaging espionage thriller. And this dichotomy overall strains the story and spreads it rather thin. At times, there are even attempts at commentary on the state of the United States role in international conflict and the moral justification of our trial-less imprisonment of those in Guantanamo Bay. But this is juxtaposed right next to cringe inducing Hollywood hacking and a rather tired and cliche cast of characters. Charlie is the embodiment of all the stereotypical hacker tropes, messy clothes, awkward jokes, and all. Briggs is the up-and-comer eager to prove himself, torn between his former career in the CIA and his new, rather above—the-law position in Sam’s Crew. Grimm is a ball-busting, hard-nosed provider of intel who shares a rather strange amoutn of sexual tension with Sam considering she spent the last game lying, betraying, and shooting him. She’s also been made to look much less homely than before. But I guess that’s the creative license afforded by the rather confusing gulf between sequel and reboot which this game occupies. Sam himself is what really makes this game feel like a reboot. There’s acknowledgement of past events of earlier games, and his daughter Sarah continues to grow, but Sam looks and sounds much younger than before. The closest comparison I can think of is when they replace James Bond. The history is there, the cast is there, some of the same players are there, but the tone and the central character is dramatically different. But I assure you I am not comparing this new Sam to Daniel Craig’s invigorating take on 007. Fischer is frankly a rather shallow character this time around. Full of youth and vigor and almost none of the cynicism or dry humor of his previous incarnations. I can understand why this is game where Michael Ironsides finally gave up on the series. Whereas he once described Fischer’s character as “a tool that had been used one too many times,” this interpretation of Fischer is a tool that is very much in working order and gung-ho ready to go do whatever is necessary for the Stars and Stripes. There is occasional friction between him and the crew around him, and even some with the higher ups in the government, but Sam’s attitude and “been there, done that” sort of look on life from earlier entries is altogether gone. And it’s certainly missed.But playing action games for quality storytelling and compelling characterization is like watching wrestling for storytelling and characterization. You’ll occasionally be thrown a bone, but you’re missing the point. Splinter Cell is at it’s best between the cutscenes and that stays true here. And, largely, this is a very old-school feeling stealth game. while there is still the mark and execute “press Y to kill everyone” feature introduced in Conviction, it seemed much harder to reliably use in my Realistic difficulty playthrough. Many enemies wear helmets and a single shot to the head will do little more than♥♥♥♥♥♥them off and make your presence known. So hand-to-hand takedowns or Sam’s plethora of gadgets are generally better options than gunfire. And that’s if you choose to engage them at all. For the first time outside of a Hitman game that I can recall, the game actively rewards the player for leaving enemies alone altogether. For every checkpoint you reach, you’ll be rewarded with points for every enemy you left entirely undisturbed. And it really motivates stealthy players to do their best to get by undetected and unnoticed. I found myself feeling guilty if I couldn’t find a  way to ghost through a section. This active rewarding of a ghostly play style is a lesson and a tactic that absolutely needs to be adopted by more stealth games (I’m looking at you, Thief 2014.)But whether you choose to avoid, attack from the shadows, or altogether mow down those that oppose you, the game does a good job of  giving you feedback on your performance. Everything you do in a level feeds into one of three gameplay categories: Ghost, Panther, and Assault. At the end of every level you’ll be given a cash total for your performance in all three categories. And if you max out a certain category, you’ll be given even greater rewards for it. So while realistically speaking you’ll have a mixture of all three at the end of every mission, you’ll want to try and really focus on one playstyle in order to maximize your monetary gains. And those gains are used to upgrade your guns, your stealth suit, or your various support functions your crew offers from the plane. This game really just gets it right where it matters. There are indeed a few minor annoyances I had which could be a major thorn in the side of other players, though. There is a whole section where you play as Briggs, the other operative on the plane, that plays out as a first person shooter. You can still ghost your way through, but the game really encourages you in this section to play it like Call of Duty. It really stuck out to me. There are also a few other sections where the non-combat routes are decidedly less emphasized than the direct approach.

												Having played a sufficent ammount to reveiw this game, (a mistake I made with stalker clear sky) I can safetly say that it is awesome! I should probably say that this reveiw is only about the campagin, not co-op or "Spies vs. Mercs" (Multiplayer). I have played a few stealth games, such as far cry 3, and the Arkham Games (i hope i'm spelling that right), but I am not a super stealth master. That being said this game is hard as F***ing nails. The AI is smart, you arent a bullet spounge and ammo is scarce. There are quite a few gadgets and toys you can unlock to f*** with your enemies, such as the noise maker, the smoke bomb, the tri-rotor, and my favorite, the sticky camera. There are a few problems with the game, the main one being the cover system. In my opinion it sucks total♥♥♥♥♥and has made me rage quit more than once. The default keys are q to enter cover and space to jump out. The problem is that it seems to always think you are pressing space when you are pressing q. There are a few minor bugs, but it was mostly bug free. The game play is brutal and satisfying if you go down the assassin route, and tense and slow if you go down the ghost route (you dont kill anyone and don't alert gaurds). I really don't like going down the tank route because its just sorta boring if you do cause you don't have action game ammo or health, so it seems a bit pointless and unfair. Overall I would give this game and 8.5/10. A great game with a few minor issues that sometimes affect gameplay, and a pointless play style.

content:
Posted: February 20
												Given what a letdown Double Agent and Conviction were, I wasn't expecting anything special when I played the game. Yet despite using the same game engine as Conviction, the series finally returns to its stealth roots and delivers an amazing stealth game on par with Chaos Theory.One of the game's main strengths is in its map design. Each map is its own small, self-contained open world environment filled with hidden passageways and alternate routes. These secret paths are so common that you'll go out of your way to find them, and it's really rewarding to find, for example, an intricate set of pipes and ledges you can climb to pass by 8+ guards unnoticed.The other main draw is the game's sheer level of customizability. Each mission rewards you with cash that can be used to upgrade your armor, weapons and gadgets. Unlike previous games, you can now carry up to 8 gadgets, including a user operated drone and an ultra powerful crossbow (stun gun variant) with 4 different firing modes. In fact, you're supplied with so many gadgets that you can't even go through all of them in a single mission (assuming one used per guard).In addition, each mission provides a ranking system for 3 different playstyles: Ghost, Panther and Assault. A Ghost style is classic stealth, Assault style means getting detected and duking it out in combat, and Panther is somewhere in between. This mechanic alone is great for replayability since you have a reason to beat any given mission at least 3 times, each time being such a vastly different experience it's almost like playing a new level. For instance, you can beat a level without so much as knocking out a single guard, then play that level again making liberal use of frag grenades, incendiary grenades, proximity mines and sniper rifle shots.Even the missions themselves have much needed variety compared to previous titles. While there is the standard fare campaign, there's also about an equal amount of Grim missions  where your objective is to either neutralize X hostiles, hack 3 terminals or even fight off waves of enemies, and the missions themselves vary in how well suited they are to a particular playstyle.Probably my biggest complaint is the storyline. Given you can beat missions in more or less any order you want, it has the effect of making the plot feel disjointed and confusing. Then there's just something about the dialogue and voice acting that comes across as silly, as if you're watching a Spy Kids movie with adults. It got to the point where I would actually skip cutscenes I hadn't seen before. If you play games for story, you should probably look elsewhere.My other minor complaint is the lack of online activity, but that's forgivable given the game is already 4 years old.

												Having played a sufficent ammount to reveiw this game, (a mistake I made with stalker clear sky) I can safetly say that it is awesome! I should probably say that this reveiw is only about the campagin, not co-op or "Spies vs. Mercs" (Multiplayer). I have played a few stealth games, such as far cry 3, and the Arkham Games (i hope i'm spelling that right), but I am not a super stealth master. That being said this game is hard as F***ing nails. The AI is smart, you arent a bullet spounge and ammo is scarce. There are quite a few gadgets and toys you can unlock to f*** with your enemies, such as the noise maker, the smoke bomb, the tri-rotor, and my favorite, the sticky camera. There are a few problems with the game, the main one being the cover system. In my opinion it sucks total♥♥♥♥♥and has made me rage quit more than once. The default keys are q to enter cover and space to jump out. The problem is that it seems to always think you are pressing space when you are pressing q. There are a few minor bugs, but it was mostly bug free. The game play is brutal and satisfying if you go down the assassin route, and tense and slow if you go down the ghost route (you dont kill anyone and don't alert gaurds). I really don't like going down the tank route because its just sorta boring if you do cause you don't have action game ammo or health, so it seems a bit pointless and unfair. Overall I would give this game and 8.5/10. A great game with a few minor issues that sometimes affect gameplay, and a pointless play style.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Blacklist is, in essence, an improved Conviction, with a touch of Chaos Theory, and a much simpler version of MGS Peace Walker's Mother Base system thrown in a blender. All of that with the multiplayer Spies Vs Mercs mode that debuted in Pandora Tomorrow. In campaign, you will do all of your prep aboard the Palidin, a large plane that serves as your headquarters and where you access missions and upgrades. You can upgrade weapons, your suit, gadgets, goggles, and even the plane itself with currency you earn by playing the game. Players that hated how conviction focused more on combat than stealth will rejoice that, much like in the early games, you can complete most missions without killing, or even interacting with enemies at all. In fact, the game has a scoring system that values stealth above combat. Also, the night vision goggles are back, with the sonar mode available as an upgrade (I hated using the Sonar in coviction, but I think it works much better here, especially after a few upgrades). Also, the game handles being in shadows (which caused you to play most of Conviction in black and white) in a simple and elegant way. The lights on your suit simply flare up, telling you that you are more hidden. If you liked Coviction, you will like this one too. If you are a hardcore fan of the gameplay in Chaos theory, I would say you should seriously consider blacklist. In my opinion, it is one of the best stealth-action games I've played.

												A German commercial on TV said that this is the best Splinter Cell game released so far - I can only agree. It's the hardest Splinter Cell existing so far: Guard dogs already in Level 1, armored enemies in Level 2, special enemies with goggles which can see you in the darkness, snipers from far distance who have the same goggles, cameras and armored enemies with an extra shield, explosive mines on the ground and lasers will be found in the upcoming levels. There are a lot of new weapons, upgrades for your body + weapons. The animation is very well done. The characters look so real, Ubisoft did a great job here. Their face expressions are awesome. You don't even play as Sam Fisher all the time in story mode - you will play as his comrade Briggs as well, who has a completely different playstyle. This game will never get boring!The only stuff which is not so nice is of course that UPlay stuff and that I always had to change the video settings to maximum when I started the game, it didn't save all the time. But all in all, a must-have for every stealth game lover and Splinter Cell fan!

												One of the newer games that I actually enjoyed. While I was disappointed by Conviction and its amount of forced action, I was pleasantly surprised with Blacklist, it kind of felt like I was playing Chaos Theory again. I fancy games with upgrade systems and well shoot this game has one, weapons, weapon upgrades, fancy different colored lights, cool suits. You can play the game any way you want, run in and blast people, stealthily kill people, or even just completely avoid everyone maybe knocking some guys out on the way. Theres quite a few missions you can play cooperatively with a friend or so, as well as there being the reintroduction of the SvM game mode, where Spies have to hack terminals while Mercenaries have to take them out and defend them. Of course its not as glorious as Chaos Theory's was but this game has its own cool things about it. I still prefer the maps and the progression through said maps in Chaos Theory, where as each terminal would unlock the next area and the Spy team would win by hacking all of the terminals. The campaign in this game is actually fun to play through and very interesting, though I do miss Michael Ironside voicing Sam Fisher. Definitely a step up from the unplayable Double Agent and the more actiony Conviction.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												As a generic, cover-based third-person shooter, it's an average game. Think "Uncharted" or "The Last of Us", except all the exploration, environmental puzzle solving, and character development is stripped out, leaving only the combat.The single-player experience is a series of combat arenas littered with waist-high walls. Each zone punctuated with a resupply cache at every checkpoint. It feels like a compilation of maps meant for the co-op mode of Conviction and it shows. Aside from the story missions, there are several game modes for the missions (no detection, clear the room, and clear the room for X waves).It's arguable that replayability is built in to the maps due to the score attack mechanism which grades you on your performance in non-lethal (Batman), silent lethal (Solid Snake), and noisy (Michael Bay) playstyles. Why a secret agent -- with a history in covert wetwork -- would be rewarded or even commended for kicking down doors and emptying an auto-shotty into a warehouse full of armored goons is beyond me.Once again, the concept of darkness is binary, as it was since Double Agent (PC/360). Due to the large number of enemies with night vision goggles and flashlights or the environments which are lit with dozens of light sources per square foot (many of which are ambient or otherwise indestructable), using shadows -- the original hallmark of the Splinter Cell series -- is pretty much useless, anyway.Stealth is no longer about stalking your prey, waiting for the perfect time to strike from the shadows. Instead, "stealth" has devolved to camping at a corner, dangling from an overhead ledge, or just sprinting up behind an enemy (provided you've specced your equipment for maximum stealth) and mashing the kill button. Speaking of overhead ledges, senior citizen Sam Fisher is more nimble and spry than ever before, able to scale the 10-foot high walls of an office building with the ease of a young assassin Ezio Auditore.Haven't bothered with the competitive multiplayer mode, so I can't comment on it.Much like Conviction, this is Splinter Cell in name only. If you must buy, wait for a deep discount. Better yet, just buy an Assassin's Creed title as that's pretty much the direction that this franchise is headed.

												Game : Splinter Cell BlacklistScore : 7/10Summary :Overal Splintercell Blacklist brings back the old feeling Chaos Theory used to have, It's a game where the developers acctualy did their best to bring back that good old feeling of trying to stealth past enemies without being deteced, something that Double Agent lacked in my oppinion. The singleplayer is a nice storyline with a nice extra added feature to upgrade your plane, upgrading this said plane will give you advantages on the battlefield, from better radar to better goggles.Considering i have played every Splinter cell series ever released on PC i think i know what i'm talking about by saying this is probably the best Splinter Cell they have released since Chaos Theory.When it comes to Multiplayer they worked hard to try and get that old feeling back that Chaos Theory used to have, unfortunately i still feels a bit chunky sometimes however i have over 100+ hours in on Multiplayer, i have to say tho, i played it without a proper team, if you have friends that want to play it aswell i can easily imagine you hit the 200+ hours.The Coop is pretty good aswell, although i suggest playing that with a friend aswell on LAN or Teamspeak, it makes the experience so much better!All in all this game surpasses Double Agent and Conviction by far, they really got the old Splinter Cell feeling back and i for one can not wait until they start working/releasing the next one!Good things about Splinter cell Blacklist - A nice new feature to upgrade your plane to make things a bit easyer in Campaign Mode- They smoothened out the upgrading/buying of new gear- Good gameplay, after 5/10 minutes of playing i got the feeling back and it felt like i never left- Versus/Multiplayer is a HUGE step forward and getting close to what Chaos Theory used to be- No significant gamebreaking bugsBad- The launch was a bit bad with Multiplayer not really working although all issues are resolved for me- At the start of Versus you feel overwhelmed by not knowing all the controls- I understand some things change, but i don't like the new voice of Sam Fisher :'( nor that he looks younger!- I hope they release some patches with new maps somethimes ( NOT DLC the game on itself is expensive enough ) All in all Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell Blacklist is a nice addition to the Splinter Cell franshise, if you liked Chaos Theory i suggest you buy this one as well.-Please note this review is written on the base of my oppinion.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I would not buy, I got it on sale and I still feel cheated. I gave Ubisoft another chance since I was feeling like playing a good Splinter Cell game and my friends had said good things about this game but now I am really wishing that Steam had a 12 hour return policy or something.I played this game for 4 hours or so right after installing it and granted that is not alot of time, but after having to replay the the first mission 3 times before I found out that the game ONLY saves if you have Uplay in Online mode and even then ONLY of you have cloud sync enabled, and after playing through the campaign for a few of the main missions, the first stage of all the side missions and giving the MP a go, I was dissappointed by the fact it is not really a stealth game.It is just another third person shooter commando game with cover based stealth elements added to appease fans of the series, yet Ubisoft fails to understand why we want those elements in the game at all. The Paladin base plane is a cool, if clumsily implemented, addition and I was hoping I would be able to go around interacting with the crew but business-woman-Rebecca, black-Sean and Bug Eyes don't serve any purpose other than to be menus that you have to click through in order to upgrade the plane or buy equipment. The one opportunity that I found for character development was a phone that you can call your daughter on after each mission and that results in awkwardly short conversations about what is going on usually followed by a "keep your chin up kiddo" remark before Sam hangs up the phone.If you are expecting something similar at all to the first 3 games (the good ones imo and I would go buy them again right now if they weren't still charging 7 dollars for 12 year old technology) you are going to be dissappointed. This one forces you, at regular intervals to go on shooting rampages, there are entire side missions focused around having shootouts in the streets (although you can stealth your way through those too, but that always consists of looping around behind them and using cover based neck chops), and it just feels like the game expects you go around neck chopping everyone you see and shooting people up with your Hitman Absolution style jedi powers with all the little gadgets you get ranging from situational to completely useless. I mean, I thought the whole purpose of the Splinter Cell program was to bring an experienced older guy, Sam Fischer, back into combat scenarios that he was too old to be in by using revolutionary stealth tactics and superior technology but that doesn't seem to matter anymore. Sam looks, acts and sounds 10 years younger in this game than he ever did and the new voice acting makes sure you can never escape that, plus he just looks angry all the time.As a side note, on top of everything else there are so many recycled features in this game, that by the time I had been playing for a couple hours it actually felt like I was playing Assassins Creed 3 with a Splinter Cell reskin. I ended up uninstalling this game, feeling like I wasted my money and that one of my favorite series' has finally admitted it will never return to it's roots.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Great, fun and well designed. Blacklist doesn't look like much on the outside but once played, the experience you get is a near flawless one that gives you delightful fun and fulfilment. Taking the new gameplay mechanics from Conviction while also bringing back the stealth aspects most notable in past games, Blacklist manages a good balance between this combination that ultimately proves successful. This time, you're given the freedom on how to truly play, with a ranking system that judges your performance based on three playstyles: Assault (shoot and kill, screw alarms), Panther (get detected but still go silent) and Ghost (total stealth, nobody knows you were ever there). Ghost, of course, gives the most points, thus being a good incentive to follow but albeit a challenging one. The game however, often assumes the path of Panther as its default, which can be quite an annoyance; seeing some scenarios play out like soldiers charging out of doors in search for you even when your existence shouldn't even be known if Pure Ghost is played. Makes no sense, but nevertheless, the player is forced to go along with it either way.Customization is vast: you're allowed to choose each piece of apparel on you, ranging from boots to even the color of the lights. There's also large assortment of gadgets to choose from, ranging from the silent to the loud. Lethal weapons like sniper rifles may be more advantaged over others but this advantage is held back by the points system that awards no-kills over kills.  It may sound discouraging, but you will eventually find the game flooding you with so much money anyway. Levels are smartly laid out and designed with a focus on non-linearity to give for multiple entryways, shortcuts and routes that different players will take. Settings and environments are never always the same, allowing for more variety and change in scenery. The first half of the game takes place largely in the Middle East though, a fine differiation from Convictions cramped building maps.The story follows Sam Fisher finally taking up the reign as a official covert operative once more, now in a newly formed Fourth Echelon tasked to take down the bad guys who are some bunch of generic terorrists... obviously.The premise is typical of the esponiage genre but fitting in bringing back nostalgia and comfort in the good ol' days of Chaos Theory.  Sam Fisher is no longer voiced by the familiar Michael Ironside, which makes him sounding a little softer in tone. But seriously, who cares about how these characters talk?The plot is a rather straightfoward one, from start to end, but proves sastisfying enough but with an ending that might leave scratching your head. One new feature in the game is the complete lack of a proper main menu. Instead, your flying ship, the Paladin, is the main menu. It's the place where you get to run about silly and free, and customize your s**** , select missions and stuff. An innovative move, clearly taken in inpsiration from Bioware's Mass Effect series.Overall, Blacklist still truimphs as a true SC game, once again bringing back the glory and origins of the franchise.  It can definitely be regarded to me as one of the, if not, the most refined stealth game of the 7th generation.4.5/5

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Overall I enjoyed my time playing the game. However as a Splinter Cell fan since day one I felt let down. The voice actor change probably left the biggest dissapointment for me, especially knowing Michael Ironside supposedly coached the new actor. Somehow every game as Sam gets older, he gets buffer and more agile. I wished at this point they did a batman beyond thing and just had a new splinter cell be the main character, like briggs. As with conviction, parts of the story are impossible to do 100% stealth although I tried very much on perfectionist to hand to hand kill only without getting detected. The story itself isn't bad but doesn't leave a sense of urgency for what's actually happening. Most of that is done through calling your daughter which feels weird considering both actors sound to be the same age. They nicely took from Conviction though and improved upon its faults gameplay wise and took on a more Double Agent (next gen version) style of knowing if you are hidden or not, basically no more color desaturation.Co-op itself was very fun for the most part. The briggs missions started and ended fun but some missions seemed near impossible to stealth or literally were impossible to stealth, especially with the highly annoying re-addition of dogs since I believe Pandorra Tomorrow. The briggs missions also were the only story based co-op missions. The 3 others were very much like deniable ops from conviction. Charlie missions are wave based and after doing one for the full 20 rounds with loud weapons, my friend and me decided we did not enjoy them whatsoever. Kobin missions did give the more classic splinter cell vibe and can be compared to hunter missions in conviction. Grimm missions were also quite fun as they were similar to infiltration from conviction with a mix of added objectives.Multiplayer is back in its true form. I've not actaully touched on mutiplayer in the PC version too much but I did play it considerably on console. At this point if you are just getting into the game, you may want to play with only friends or else you will find yourself unable to do much as the learning curve has always been high with SvM. I found that the new SvM blacklist mode to be the best of them all giving you 4 mercs vs 4 spys and having to try and hack 3 terminals. Unlike Double Agent, you dont actually need to maintain presence at the terminal, just in the region. There is a throwback mode to Chaos Theory/Pandora Tomorrow which is 2v2 Classic. I didn't actually enjoy it too much considering how much I played Chaos Thoery SvM. There's nothing wrong with it, it plays quite well but I found myself liking the 4v4 mode with new stuff more. There are also other modes which combine spies and mercs on one team however they just don't feel that much fun to play even though I liked the old gen SvS in Double Agent. The addition of loadouts added a much new feel to SvM. I personally liked it because it gives you more ways to counter the opposition. If you dont like that though, the Classic mode will be perfect as it limits loadouts.Overall I do recommend this game because it is fun and well put together, but at this point its only worth getting if you desperately want the story or have a friend to play co-op with. If you've never played a Splinter Cell game before, then I think it is a great game to get into as there isn't really any expectations. Getting it for multiplayer is questionable as the community is small and learning curve high with most people playing max level now.

												9.0/10Splinter Cell Blacklist is a very good game even for people who have never played a single other splinter cell game like me which is REALLY good. In Splinter Cell Blacklist you play as Sam Fisher an off the books man (because it never specifies which database he works for like CIA or FBI) who is assigned the leader of the 4th Echelon. The 4th Echelon is a big plane with everything you need on the ground but in their too. In the 4th Echelon you can explore the plane which is actually pretty small all things considered but you can still talk with your crew after every mission and they will have a different thing so say before that mission, but they will keep saying the same thing over and over after the mission if you click on them over and over (if that makes sense). So now onto the crew, you have Anna Grimsdottir who plans out before the mission, then you have Charlie a computer tech genius and can make very useful stuff for your missions, Briggs is another part of the team and here's his background. Briggs has just transfered from CIA and is Sam's partner so to speak although you play him in one mission in first person. WARNING DO NOT READ NEXT PART IF HAVE NOT STARTED OR FINISHED SPLINTER CELL BLACKLIST  You also play him in the last mission but you never know until the end of the mission  . Last but not least you have Kobin a man who faked killing Sam Fisher's daughter (which Sam still holds a grudge about) but is the only connection they have to "The Engineers" and they are the antagonist of the game but the main antagonist is  Majid Sadiq  . One more thing before I list the Pros and Cons of this game Splinter Cell Blacklist is a very stealthy game and test your stealthness and logic of sneaking around and knocking out or killing people very well. P.S. Splinter Cell Blacklist also has a multiplayer where each one of the crew members has a mission for you and the missions make you feel like you're not even in multiplayer but almost like they are one of the campaign missions. P.P.S. You also can do parkour and find hidden paths to use to your advantage to have a very stealthy aspect and make you feel like you are actually doing stealth.Pros:1. When you are on the 4th Echelon you can upgrade the plane to unlock weapons, heal faster in solo and co-op play2. The graphics are astounding for such a stealthy game. 3. Some missions are in day and some are in night which gives you a reason to say stealth is not only achieved at night but also in day.4. There is parkour in this game where stealth can be useful and you can knock out people that come to close to the edge.5. When you go behind someone or are crouched around a corner waiting for them to come near you you can knock out, kill (which you can do at anytime if you don't want to knock out people), you can use them as a human shield if you are in danger.6.You can capture High Value Targets and then get money which you can use to upgrade your suit, weapons, gadgets that Charlie made, or even upgrade the plane.7. You can upgrade your goggles to be much better than the prievious set of goggles you had and you can even get sonar vison to see enemy through walls whom you can then mark them if you want to do an execution ( In this game that means if commit an execution that means you will point your gun at them it turns into slow motion and you shoot them in the head and don't even need to press a single button while it happens).8. When you knock out or kill someone you can then pickup their body and hide them in a dumpster, hide them in the bathroom and close the door, throw them over a ledge, throw them off a roof, or just leave the bodies there if you're in a rush.9. Before every mission you will go into your loadout screen and Charlie will recommend that gadgets to use in that mission which is some VERY valuable information to have to be properly prepared. (Note you don't have to use those gadgets it's just recommended fo that mission).10. This may not seem important but you can also round corners, climb over ledges or bosxes or the cover your using to hide from enemies.11. If you get caught and hopefully don't die you can hide in the shadows and the enemies will know there's an intruder but not know his exact location.12. When you get caught a white silouhuette will show where the enemy saw you and you can use this to your advantage and maybe leave a "present" for them there as a "suprise".13. In pretty much every mission there is a point where two enemies will be talking to eachother and what you can do is A.Execute them B.Knock them out with sleeping gas or a proximity shocker (basically a mine but if someone get's close to it they get electricuted and knocks them out) or C.Just save them for later.14. If you knock someone out it actually gives you a bonus since it's harder to knock them out instead of just utting a bullet in their braincase.15. There are 3 ways you can do a mission Ghost: You do a mission with no one dying and everyone knocked out and not a single enemy detects you. Panther: You do a mission where you get caught but then don't get caught again and kill alot of your enemies like a panther, get it? and Combat where you get detected and dont stealth and kill or knockout everyone. P.S. For Panther you can also knock out people but i wanted to you to picture how a panther stealths but kills its prey while not getting seen alot.16. If you join someone else's multiplayer game you can play as Briggs in third person and not just Sam Fisher.Now for the CONS:1. The inside of the 4th Echelon is very small with not alot of exploration becuase if you look from it from the outside it looks HUGE.2. If you want to play with your friends on steam you MUST have their Uplay account on your Uplay friendslist since the game runs on Uplay.3. The first mission you play as Briggs you can only kill people not knock them out, it's in first person so it's much harder to stealth (although you can but doesn't really feel like it) and if you throw say a proximity shocker you don't know where it's going to land since you don't see the arc as you do when you play as Sam Fisher in THIRD-person.4. Although there is a laser sight mod for the gun that you can buy and a holosight you CANNOT acutually aim down the sights of your piston which can seem a little frustrating at times since you can with your silenced submachine gun if you get the ACOG sight or another sight for it.5. There is only 3 different type of enemies: The unarmored ones , Armored ones, and drone operators  who have a little drone with a big red light slowly go around trying to detect enemies (aka you the player) and if you shoot them once they're knocked out and the drone operator puts out another drone or 2 shots and they explode, Drone Operators also jam your vison until they are A.Knocked Out or B.Killed P.S. Sorry about forgetting to tell you the plot so The Engineers who are the antagonist made a publice announcement to bring all of America's soldier's because their leader  Majid Sadiq  believes that the American troops in 153 countries are in countries that they don't belong. So Sam Fisher is assigned to the 4th Echelon (the plane) and a crew to stop the blacklist because if America doesn't bring back their soldiers alot of people will die each day. Which is why you must stop The Engineers and the Blacklist so you know not a big deal  I'm being sarcastic  .So I hope you found this review helpful and thank you for reading this before buying just to get some background information. See ya later! :)

												Cool gameplay. Cool music. Cool skin-tight latex body suits that demonstrate the effectiveness of P90X.  However, the lack of Michael Ironside's voice and performance prevents Blacklist from reaching maxmium coolness. A weathered man, a father, a war vet, I imagine Sam Fisher is pushing 55, yet in this rendtion of the Splinter Cell series, he is voiced by a pubescent child who is prone to lashing out at his inner party. It's as if they're making some lackadaisical attempt to turn Sam Fisher into a young and hip action icon that is possessed by teen angst, opposed to the sardonically dark humour that we've grown accustomed to over the years. I don't mind if they're trying to reinvent the protagonist of Splinter Cell in order to appeal to a younger generation, but if that's the case, put Sam Fisher to rest and don't sully his image more than you already have. Introduce a new Splinter Cell--this reverse aging thing is just too weird for me.Also, Fisher, arguably one of the most skillful agents of espionage of all time, lacks the ability to take cover in a standing position, which I found odd.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This isn't a bad game, per se, but it is terribly disappointing to me.  Conviction, its predecessor, was absolutely amazing and I therefore had very high hopes for Blacklist.  Where Conviction had a complete single-player campaign along with a variety of co-op missions that could be played solo, Blacklist has a whole bunch of co-op stuff mixed into the solo campaign;  I despise being unable to complete missions, unlock gear, etc in the solo campaign without doing online stuff.  The levels inside the campaign also feature a lot of co-op only stuff - doors, passages, and more that can't be done in a solo game.  Worse still, some of the unlocks require playing an iPhone/Android game and synching it with your Uplay account.  Honestly, doesn't UBI already have enough of my information without resorting to installing spyware on my phone?In terms of actual gameplay, the game again suffers compared with its predecessor.  Nearly every enemy on every map in every difficulty is wearing a magic helmet that can somehow prevent all damage from a supersonic 7.62.  Seriously, you pop them in the head and they just turn around to see how shot them.  It absolutely ruins the mark & execute mechanic (armored targets don't die to the execution), and takes a huge amount of fun out of the game for me.  It simply should not be safer to enter melee combat with an enemy than to cap his head with a firearm.  I suspect the developers were trying to appease the crowd that whined about Conviction being too easy and ended up producing something that appeals to neither camp.  I'll possibly continue playing long enough to finish the game, especially if I find a co-op partner, but I'm really disappointed in the game and the direction of the franchise in general.

												In my opinion, this is one of THE BEST splinter cell games out there, if not actually taking the crown. What I didn't really like about the others (cept for conviction), was the restrictions, I mean, what IF I wanted to be a gung ho kind of spy? You know, like that orc assasin in oblivion xDAll the other splinter cell games force you to be stealthy (nothing wrong with that, it's the game genre after all), but blacklist allows you to choose what you want (conviction too, a little bit). IMO in reality a spy would rather drop somebody before even giving that somebody a chance to even think about spotting him xD, so killing in a stealth game isn't really something out of character.The thing is you aren't FORCED to play any particular way in blacklist (like chaos theory). To be honest, blacklist, if played full stealth (no knockouts) is EVEN MORE stealth based than chaos theory (standing in shadows 1m away from somebody and they not noticing you isn't really stealth).When you can get by an army of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in broad daylight on perfectionist and not even be spotted once, I think that says a whole lot more about stealth than chaos theory where you just stick (mostly) to shadows... Don't get me wrong, I freaking love chaos theory xDAs I said, blacklist doesn't force you to be stealthy, if you just wanna see Fisher in badass action, let him kill everybody, I mean, I sometimes like to go around sneaking on people and then all of a sudden SHOTGUN TO THE FACE!!! xDBlacklist is also harder for pure stealth, I mean, I did 100% in chaos theory on hardest difficulty without saving and loading, couldn't do it in blacklist though... (well tbh the train bug can be excused xD).The pistol thingy in chaos theory and double agent (forgot it's name lol) made you OP in artificially illuminated areas, IMO. No such thing in blacklist.Overall if you're REALLY unbiased while criticising, you'll get that the stealth in this one FAR outclasses any other splinter cell game, if you're going for stealth, that is ;)Graphics whise, I really can't tell, I'm not a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, I usually run most of my games on the lowest to get as much FPS out of them as I can, even if I can run them at max xDSounds are amazing, but I REALLY MISS IRONSIDE!!! If I had the money, I'd pay im a few million $$$ to dub Fisher in this game xD

												I just finished the main story line and I was a bit disappointed. It is fairly short and I finished it in around 7 hours of Gameplay. I have a very decent rig, and usually got 60+ frames during gameplay and 100+ fps during cinematics. However, every now and then the FPS will drop to 10 or less during gameplay as well as cinematics. Also, I have had at least a dozen freezes or crashes during my gameplay and I have tried several solutions, from altering the .ini file to reducing graphics etc. These changes helped a bit, but did not completely clear the problem for me.Overall, I would reluctantly recommend this game. 												For a game that was released on August 20, 2013 this is still a very enjoyable ride. The voice acting deserves credit, all characters in the game provide genuine performances. Their personalities can easily be seen, i still think Briggs is a tool! The sound and graphics are top notch and all work together flawlessly to provide a very satisfying gaming experience, i was kept hooked enough to keep coming back to complete the single player campaign. The main antagonist was portrayed quite well, although it would have been great to see his real personality earlier in the game instead of only in the final segments. The controls should be noted, sometimes Sam handles a little wonky, and there can be delays between animations which mess up your timing. I played the entire SP campaign with a controller and found no significant issues with it.All in all a very enjoyable experience from start to finish. If you haven't played this game you are really missing out!

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												I just finished the main story line and I was a bit disappointed. It is fairly short and I finished it in around 7 hours of Gameplay. The gameplay itself is ok, giving you a lot of ways to go through a certain area, and it will reward you depending on your play style. There are also coop mission and online content, but I have not tried those out.However, this is such a horrible port. I have a very decent rig, and usually got 60+ frames during gameplay and 100+ fps during cinematics. However, every now and then the FPS will drop to 10 or less during gameplay as well as cinematics. It stutters horribly for a few seconds, then normalises again. Also, I have had at least a dozen freezes or crashes during my gameplay and I have tried several solutions, from altering the .ini file to reducing graphics etc. These changes helped a bit, but did not completely clear the problem for me.Overall, I would reluctantly recommend this game. It's definitely not a master piece and it's buggy, but it did provide me some decent gameplay while it lastet. I got it during a sale, and I would recommend you do the same.

												The story couldn't be anymore american. The game starts with an attack on the USA and you are Sam Fisher, the greatest patriotic spy the game industry has to offer and your goal is to rescue 'MURICA. Sam's black sidekick follows him around and helps him out whereever he can and yet Sam doesn't like him. Remember Sam's daughter whom you had to safe in S.C. Conviction? Well now you communicate with her trough your phone on your so called Paladin, a big♥♥♥♥♥Plane full of  	unnecessary scripted actions you have to make every few seconds. The game offers you a huge amount of useless gadgets. The only time I used a little RC helicopter was when the game forced me to do it. You also get a variety of grenades and other nonsense, even a rifle and yet the only thing you need is your pistol. Well actually you don't even really need that. And while you used the "Execute Mode" in Conviction quite often for reasons, you probably won't use it here at all. How's the stealth? It's Ubisofty. If you tried any of Ubisoft's past titles which included any sort of stealth (Far Cry 3, AC for example) then you might know what I'm talking about. It feels unrealistic and therefor way too easy. I won't say anything regarding the multiplayer since it's pretty much dead already.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												I'm not of the sneaking game group of people, but I enjoy it on ocassion.  Those who like full on sneak games will probably be dissapointed in this game but I like that it gives you the option to do either sneak or run and gun, (although RnG is a bit harder to succeed at) this game is best somewhere in the middle, which is a third optional playtype.overall it's an improvement over the last game, particularly how you can go back and replay older story missions with gear you've unlocked.The multiplayer is a fascinating combination of first person versus third person combat, heavy gunners with armor are in first person, which is fitting, and sneaky low armored stealth guys in third, which is also fitting.  SNeaky sem like they have the advantage but the first person guys can take them out easier if the third person guys dont get the drop on them quick enough.Overall I like this game, there's a lot of fun to be had.  So why am I giving it a negative review?Because if someone uses hacks in multiplayer you're ♥♥♥♥ed.There is NO vote kick. NO report. NO leave match option either! So if your game bugs out or someone is, using an item in their grenade slot that instant kills the entire enemy team repetively the moment the spawn back in you are literally stuck watching yourself be helpless to the hacker with no way to get rid of them or to even escape them without alt-F4ing/end programing or reseting your computer.Literally nothing you can do about it.  How could Ubisoft over look such a thing?  And yes, that was literally what happened to me and despite loving this game I immdiatly quit out, discovered there's literally nothing you can do, and just uninstalled it right away and have not been back since.A brother of a friend got glitched into an object and couldn't quit out.So if you only play single player, or can avoid hackers, it's a fun game worth a few play through.  But, hackers ruined it, ♥♥♥♥ it.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												While there is fun to be had in Splinter Cell Blacklist the controls end up causing more frustration than fun and with no alternate control schemes you are forced to play the game the way the designers want you to play and not the way most comfortable for you.There are seperate buttons for climbing up, climbing down, and sticking to and off of cover.  Getting used to these is fine but in the heat of the moment when a guard comes up behind you and all you want to do is pull away from a wall or quickly drop from a ledge your going to panic and your perfect run will be ruined.  Ideally a context sensitive "use button" or smarter "sticky" cover system would have done wonders.Not to mention people who have never played a Splinter Cell game before will find even the Rookie difficulty hair pullingly insane.  The game is designed to lock out the most usefull tools that could help Rookie players until you can earn them much later in the game.  Things like expanded radar, improved sonar vision, and enemy facing on the radar would have made the earlier experience for new players a much smoother ride.One of the most attrocious features the developers overlooked for the PC version of the game is the ability to save when you want.  This is something PC stealth gamers have enjoyed for years but in this modern age of autosaves and checkpoints it is nowhere to be found in this game.  Enjoy doing side missions where you have to kill 35 enemies and bust on the last one, or where you have to complete multiple objectives without being spotted once and blow it right at the end.  It's just too risky to save before trying out a really fun and neat looking manuever so its best just to play it safe and boring.If you can get past the unwieldy controls and the lack of a save feature this is a well made content rich game.  For new players you'll have to put up with a lot of frustration and replaying extremely long stretches of gameplay over and over and over again.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Ok. Where do I begin?Halp?Well to start off my review I'm going to say that I've been a Tom Clancy fan ever since Conviction and earlier. I had faith in Blacklist and I desire another Splintercell. But first, lets talk about Blacklist...The Blacklist campaign is basically Sam Fisher working for 4th Echelon (founded by the President) and are working towards taking down the so called Engineers - a terrorist group who launch attacks on American every seven days.
